description.narrative: 1. Ensure the development and effective delivery of responsive, accountable and locally-appropriate security and justice, as a means towards conflict transformation 2. Challenge gender norms that cause and perpetuate conflict and insecurity 3. Prevent and reduce the impact of external factors on security and peace, including the proliferation and misuse of conventional weapons and the implementation of state-building/stabilization strategies with potential to fuel conflict. 4. Ensure international political, economic, development and security engagement in conflict-affected contexts is sensitive to conflict dynamics and contributes to sustainable peace 5.Promote accountable, fair and inclusive governance systems and peacebuilding processes that address the root causes of conflict.

Core support to Saferworld who works to prevent conflict and to strengthen human security through supporting local, national and international efforts for peace and security. Beside policy and advocacy work on international level, Saferworld is working in around twenty countries/regions towards three "peace conditions" - people's participation in transition from conflict and in peacebuilding; access to justice and effetive means to manage abuse and injustice driving conflict; and decision-makers use their power to favour justice and equality.

Kärnstöd till Saferworld som arbetar för att förebygga konflikt och stärka mänsklig säkerhet genom att stödja lokal, nationella och internationella anstängningar för fred och säkerhet. Förutom policy- och påverksansarbete på internationell nivå arbetar Saferworld i ett 20-tal länder och regioner för att tre "peace conditions" ska förverkligas; att människor deltar och har en aktiv roll i övergång från konflikt och i fredsbyggande insatser; har tillgång till rättvisa och effektiva kanaler för att hantera övergrepp och orättvisor som driver konflikten; och makthavare utövar sin makt för att främja ett rättvist och jämlikt samhälle.

sector.narrative: Civilian peace-building, conflict prevention and resolution

policy-marker.narrative: Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention on Biological Diversity
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention to Combat Desertification
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Adaptation
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Mitigation
Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: During the implementation period between April 1st, 2014 to March 31st 2017, Saferworld has worked across 20 countries and territories with over 60 partners and a wide network of associates. The overall aim has been to contribute to the reduction of conflict and insecurity through both a thematic and geographic spread, covering both Africa, Asia, MENA and Eastern Europe. They have conducted activities both at the individual and community level as well as with civil society actors, authorities and external actors at the national, regional and policy, research and advocacy level. Examples of results that have been achieved: - In Yemen, despite security deteriorations, Saferworld has throughout the programme period maintained their presence when many other organisations and civil society actors left the country. During this time, Saferworld instead adapted their activities and designed a WhatsApp-based participatory remote learning course for peacebuilding activists that enabled people from different parts of the country and conflict divides to participate. This demonstrated an effective way to reach people in difficult to access locations with little resources. The peacebuilding course was well received and participants of the course have as a result conducted follow-on trainings and activities. - In South Sudan, efforts included strengthening community action groups (CAGs) in their skills, confidence and capacity to take collaborative action to counter threats to security and build peaceful communities. As a result, eight CAGs successfully solved local-level disputes and conflict issues such as cyclical cattle rustling, building new roads, revenge killings, disputes over farmlands, rescue of abducted children and the deployment of police to protect civilians. Saferworld’s efforts in South Sudan further included providing technical input to the drafting and redrafting of the national Assembly’s passed firearms bill – the first ever Small Arms and Light Weapons (SALW) law in the country. - In Somalia, following Saferworld’s advocacy, the Somaliland National Electoral Commission (NEC) changed their voter education strategy to have elders encouraging community members to register to vote, which resulted in higher voter registration numbers, new regions being reched and extended public participation in regions that were previously resistant. - Twelve external actors, including donors and multilateral agencies, took up Saferworld's and partners' recommendations on policy and practice in conflict-affected states. For example, the UK International Development Committee and the Business Committee called for a halt of arms sales to Saudi Arabia for use in Yemen. - Saferworld at the national level introduced the concept of conflict sensitivity to the Chinese Academy of International Trade and Economic Cooperation (CAITEC) under the Chinese Ministry of Commerce through field research in South Sudan. Subsequently, CAITEC requested Saferworld’s support to draft a project proposal to the CSSF, addressing conflict-sensitive economic engagement in conflict-affected countries.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
